item.title: CSCI 5675 – Advanced Game Development
item.description: CSCI 4675 / 5675 & FA 4599: Advanced Game Development Spring 2016: Monday and Wednesday in Math 118 from 3:30 to 4:45 PM. The new Innovation Lab in Library 318 is reserved on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 3:30 PM to 5:00 PM for the exclusive use of this class. Contents Course Description Instructor Prerequisites Grading Roles Policies Academic Integrity Students with Disabilities Calendar Course Description Advanced Game Development is the final, capstone-style course of the Game Development Concentration.

item.title: CSCI 5670 – Fundamentals of Game Development
item.description: Submissions 20141210-the-pitch 20141016-midterm 20141027-game-post-mortem-2 20141115-game-proposal-3-water-balloon-boys 20141116-gameplay-journal-3-the-longest-journey 20141209-research-paper-template 20141026-nts 20140928-guerrav0-01 20141013-game-proposal-2-ninja-time-strategy 20141012-gameplay-journal-2-spartacus-legends 20140929-game-post-mortem-1 20140914-gameplay-journal-1-command-and-conquer 20140909-game-proposal-1 Fall 2014, Tuesday and Thursday from 2:00 PM to 3:15 PM in Math 121 Original Website About the Class This is the first class specifically focused on video game development. It covers basic principles of game design, game history, the games industry, and technical topics specifically related to games. The projects in this class are designed to increase your awareness of and familiarity with game design tools and to help you establish a very modest portfolio.

item.title: CSCI 6250 – Big Data Analytics and Systems
CSCI 5631 – Principles of Computer Graphics
item.description: Fall 2016 Syllabus Book interactive-computer-graphics-a-top-down-approach-6e-by-edward-angel-and-dave-shreiner-pearson-2012-bbs Class Notes Java_to_C++_Transition Vectors and matrices – DmWiki angel6e01 – What is Computer Graphics? (pdf) angel6e02 – Image Formation (pdf) angel6e03 – Models and Architectures (pdf) angel6e04 – Programming with OpenGL Part 1: Background (pdf) angel6e05 – Programming with OpenGL Part 2: Complete Programs (pdf) angel6e06 – Programming with OpenGL Part 3: Shaders (pdf) angel6e07 – Programming with OpenGL Part 4: Color and Attributes (pdf) angel6e08 – Programming with OpenGL Part 5: More GLSL (pdf) angel6e09 – Programming with OpenGL Part 6: Three Dimensions (pdf) angel6e10 – Input and Interaction (pdf) angel6e11 – Working with Callbacks (pdf) angel6e12 – Geometry (pdf) angel6e13 – Representation (pdf) angel6e14 – Transformations (pdf) 1-summa_transformations-copy (pdf) angel6e15 – OpenGL Transformations (pdf) angel6e16 – Building Models (pdf) angel6e17 – Classical Viewing (pdf) angel6e18 – Computer Viewing (pdf) angel6e19 – Projection Matrices (pdf) angel6e20 – Shading I (pdf) angel6e21 – Shading II (pdf) angel6e22 – Shading in OpenGL (pdf) angel6e23 – Implementation I (pdf) angel6e24 – Implementation II (pdf) angel6e25 – Implementation III (pdf) angel6e26 – Buffers (pdf) angel6e27 – Texture Mapping (pdf) angel6e28 – OpenGL Texture Mapping (pdf) angel6e29 – Shader Applications (pdf) angel6e30 – Compositing and Blending (pdf) angel6e31 – Hierarchical Modeling I (pdf) angel6e32 – Hierarchical Modeling II (pdf) John Carmack (of Id Software) discusses lighting and shading angel6e35 – Curves and Surfaces (pdf) angel6e36 – Designing Parametric Cubic Curves (pdf) angel6e37 – Bezier and Spline Curves and Surfaces (pdf) angel6e38 – Rendering Curves and Surfaces (pdf) Homework Assignments 4631_hw_1 (My Answers) 4631_hw_2 (My Answers) homework-3 (My Answers) homework-4 (My Answers) homework-5 homework-6 Tests Midterm Final Exam Grad Papers An empirical basis for Mach bands by Lotto, Williams, and Purves Mach bands as empirically derived associations Examples example1 example2 example3 point

item.title: Sample Page
item.description: This is an example page. It’s different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this: Hi there! I’m a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas.

item.title: About Me
item.description: Edward Thomas Garcia MBA I currently work at the University of New Orleans(UNO) as a Programmer Analyst. At work, I program in PeopleSoft’s PeopleCode and SQR, Oracle SQL, and sometimes some ASP.NET (C#). I love to program and create graphics for video games. I am also enrolled at UNO as a Graduate Computer Science Student where I am currently pursuing my interests in advanced topics in video games. Courses taken:
